line_1: Well-natur'd, happy shade, forgive!
line_2: Like you I think, but cannot live.

line_1: Dwells on his Dying Lips) Forgive;
line_2: Cries, "Father, Let the Rebels Live.

line_1: Teach me to love, and to forgive,
line_2: The gen'rous spark extinct revive,

line_1: You have a daughter — Sweet, forgive
line_2: A Wolf's address — In her I live;

line_1: Too soon I can forgive;
line_2: Could I endure to live.

line_1: Speak, pitying speak, my frantic fears forgive,
line_2: Say, does my father, does my ZAMOR live?" —

line_1: And all the wrongs of madd'ning rage forgive!
line_2: Live, tender spirit, soft ACILOE live,

line_1: Slow to be angry, easy to forgive!
line_2: In social Friendship always let me live,

line_1: Can faithful William yet forgive
line_2: Granted, it shall no more survive;

line_1: Where Truth may smile, and Justice may forgive: —
line_2: These are the arts by which a thousand live,

line_1: Farewell ye distant Waves; you I forgive,
line_2: Well might you fickle prove, and Eune leave,

line_1: Farewell ye distant Waves; you I forgive,
line_2: When he, who lov'd so much, yet cou'd deceive.

line_1: For Jesu's sake our crimes forgive,
line_2: And O! when here we cease to live,

line_1: To pity, and perhaps, forgive.
line_2: And something ev'ry day they live

line_1: Delighteth to forgive.
line_2: No other plea I have,

line_1: Let Foes resent a Trespass, Friends forgive.
line_2: O'erlook the Failure: All offend, that live;

line_1: If Goodness can this bold Address forgive,
line_2: Nurs'd by your Smiles, my humble Rhymes shall live.

line_1: Almighty God, the monstrous crime forgive!
line_2: A slave, and such perhaps he still may live;

line_1: This first, unfortunate offence, forgive,
line_2: Or let thy servant here a vassal live

line_1: For she could injuries forgive,
line_2: Whate'er his faith, she could receive

line_1: The Innocents their Parent's Love forgive,
line_2: Smile at their Fate, nor know they are to live:

line_1: " Too soon I can forgive;
line_2: " Could I endure to live.

line_1: How easy to forgive!
line_2: And by thy Love I live.

line_1: For that one Act I all his Faults forgive.
line_2: To Angiers then did he Cleora leave?

line_1: A Constant Youth their Vice wou'd ne'er forgive.
line_2: Scarce will this wanton Age my Tale Believe;

line_1: He Sigh'd, and Begg'd she would his Faults forgive,
line_2: And cry'd, don't ask your wretched Child to live;

line_1: He Sigh'd, and Begg'd she would his Faults forgive,
line_2: Nor torture thus, my Soul, to see you Grieve:

line_1: And Natures Faults, let Heav'en and you forgive:
line_2: Angiers to Honour straight, and Grace retrieve,

line_1: You shall this fondness of my Muse forgive,
line_2: And tho' not in my Arms, in my soft numbers live:

line_1: Reason, if I do Err, my Crime forgive?
line_2: Angels alone, without offending live,

line_1: "Oh, Heavens!" he cried, "my first rash vow forgive!
line_2: These bind to earth, for these I pray to live!" —

line_1: Beloved of Heaven, these humble lines forgive,
line_2: That sing of Thee, and thus aspire to live.

line_1: To pity and forgive.
line_2: Our sinking hearts receive;

line_1: "As God shall judge me, Knight, we must forgive
line_2: " The frail good Man deluded here to live,

line_1: When grieved, to pray; when injured, to forgive;
line_2: And with the world in charity to live.

line_1: And little trespasses forgive,
line_2: Prone the distressed to relieve,

line_1: Can righteous Heaven the Kite forgive?
line_2: They pine — they mourn — but do not live;

line_1: And he may be rude, and yet I may forgive.
line_2: Till lost in the joy, we confess that we live,

line_1: Thou on repentance wilt forgive,
line_2: And biddest us return and live;

line_1: Too timorous to punish or forgive.
line_2: He was too proud without affronts to live,

line_1: In league with MERCY, JUSTICE may forgive
line_2: TRUTH fairly must record, and, pleas'd to live

line_1: Long may Ye sin, and long may Heav'n forgive;
line_2: Think not, for wrongs like these unscourg'd to live;

line_1: And bids us wrath and wrong forgive;
line_2: 'T is then we rightly learn to live.

line_1: Gods! can ye hear this and Forgive?
line_2: You may, for I have Heard and Live!

line_1: Purpose to slay, whilst swearing to forgive.
line_2: Doubling my Crime, I promise, and deceive;

line_1: Thy tenets, Stoic, yet we may forgive,
line_2: If in a future state we cease to live.

line_1: When pitying heaven, impatient to forgive,
line_2: Unbars the gates of light, and bids thee live;

line_1: Then nobly pity and forgive;
line_2: Slander and scorn themselves deceive,

line_1: Teach me to love and to forgive,
line_2: The generous spark extinct revive,
